Comments_List: I learned a ton about early modern Spainon topics including art, culture, religion, politics, and military.
I learned a whole lot about religious and political life in Early Modern Spain, in addition to learning how to write and research a long term paper on this period and region.

I learned about Spain in the 16th and 17th century Spain, focusing on many of the religious, economic, and international components of the rise and fall of the Spanish Empire.  In the course, students read a good deal of primary sources and literature, which I found to be very informative and practical.

Professor Eires HIST 565 Early Modern Spain extensively and comprehensively introduced and sophisticated students knowledge of fifteenth to seventeenth century Spain, its history and cultures. While enrolled in this course, students acquired multifaceted and diverse understanding of Early Modern Spain, ranging from the power dynamics between rulers and religious figures to conceptualization of ordinary individuals daily lives within official documents and literature. Furthermore, this course enabled students to analyze, compare, contrast and thus evaluate different historiographical methods and perspectives, from utilization of sources to overall academic goal of each monograph. Thus, this course demonstrated how Early Modern Spain comprised of a centralized, yet simultaneously multi-centered, dynamics of power and cultural production.
Carlos Eire does a great job of facilitating discussion and the assignments are very conducive to student learning.

The strengths lied in the syllabus, which was fantastic, and Professor Eire's knowledge, which was incredibly deep. The weaknesses were in the seminar discussions on occasion, which sometimes were a little slower, because some had probably not done the reading, but Professor Eire usually filled in for this lack of conversation.
Professor Eire was extremely engaging and helpful. The syllabus of the course was oriented toward religious topics, in particular, but all of the works were nonetheless interesting and illuminating.

This course truly honed students analytical and historiographical skills in a diverse and varied manner, due to its multidisciplinary perspective. The comprehensive characteristic of the overall syllabus presented students with multiple historiographical viewpoints, incorporating such sources as actual seventeenth century official documents and treatises, as well as modern monographs, such as that concerning the theoretical development of Golden Age Spanish Art. Furthermore, weekly class discussions gave students opportunities to comment upon different historiographical methods and utilization of primary and secondary sources, and the individual presentations enabled students to put to test their own historical and historiographical perspectives. Additionally, the term paper enabled students to sophisticate their historical and multidisciplinary knowledge, upon their pursuing a particular theme. Overall, this course consists of a comprehensive and profound demonstration of the immense historical and cultural implications of Early Modern Spain.
Yes, it is a particularly useful course for students who both study early modern Spain and study other countries during the early modern period

I would recommend this course, because Professor Eire is a really terrific teacher and mentor to his students. He puts a lot of time into helping us learn, and is really committed to making the seminar enjoyable. The material was also well-organized to all levels of learning.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in Early Modern Spain, Europe, or Latin America. This course would also be of great use to students focused on Hispanic literature or religious studies.

Indeed, I would most definitely recommend this course, since Professor Eire ensures that his students learn and acquire diverse historical, historiographical, cultural, literary and artistic knowledges concerning Early Modern Spain. Professor Eires course will introduce, sophisticate and culminate students historical and historiographical perspectives, as well as enable them to explore and develop their knowledge concerning their individual topics of interest. Via many components, such as weekly discussions, presentations and a term paper, this course comprehensively develops students academic perspectives towards Early Modern Spain. Thus, Professor Eires course will most definitely develop all students into historically and culturally aware and equipped scholars.
